questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in a primary health center. On 5th May 2023, you took a look at these 4 vaccine vials. Vial 1 had an expiry date of 4th May 2023 and the rest of the vials had an expiry date of 14th October 2023. Which of the following vials could be used?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, only vial 2 can be used.

According to the vaccine vial monitor, vial 1 and vial 2 can be used, but vial 2 is the one that was really fit for use as it had not yet expired as on 5th May 2023. Whereas, vial 1 has crossed the date of expiry.

Vial 3 and vial 4 should be discarded even though the drug has not expired. This is because the color in the inner square has matched the outer circle in vial 3 and is darker than the outer circle in vial 4.

Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are chemical indicator labels which are used to monitor the heat stability of the vaccines and are useful throughout the vaccine supply chain. The VVMs are designed to ensure that heat-damaged vaccines are not given to the patients. They also indicate preferable order of usage of the vials, thereby minimising vaccine wastage. 

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: An insured 35-year-old man, who is working as a teacher, is undergoing a vasectomy procedure. According to the Employees State Insurance Act, he would receive the cash benefit under ____.
questions.solution:
Insured persons in the productive age group undergoing sterilization procedures such as tubectomy and vasectomy are offered cash benefits under the ESI Act as enhanced sickness benefits. The enhanced sickness benefit equal to full wage is payable to insured persons undergoing sterilization for 7 days for male and 14 days for female workers. 

Other options: 

Option B: Extended sickness benefit is offered to insured people who are suffering from certain chronic diseases, for a maximum period of 2 years, in addition to the 91 days of leave they are entitled to under the sickness benefit. During this period, they are paid about 80% of the average daily wages. The insured person should have been working for a continuous period of 2 years. There are 34 listed diseases for which the extended sickness benefit can be availed. 

Option D: Sickness Benefit is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

questions.text:
An 18-month-old baby was brought with complaints of fever and fast breathing. According to IMNCI, what should be the respiratory rate to diagnose this baby with pneumonia?

IMNCI: Integrated management of neonatal and childhood illness
questions.solution:
An 18-month-old baby presenting with fever and fast breathing should have a respiratory rate of >40 to be diagnosed with pneumonia according to IMNCI.

According to the IMNCI, three key clinical signs are used to assess a sick child with suspected pneumonia:

  • Respiratory rate (RR): distinguishes children who have pneumonia from those who do not. Children are classified under pneumonia if:
    • > 60 breaths per minute if age  is < 2 months 
    • > 50/min RR for infants 2 months to 12 months
    • > 40/min RR for children 12 months to 5 years of age
  • Lower chest wall indrawing refers to the indrawing of the lower chest wall with respect to the child's breathing and indicates pneumonia
  • Stridor indicates those with severe pneumonia requiring hospital admission.

The revised classification of acute respiratory infections is simplified to include only two categories of pneumonia:

  • Cough and cold, no pneumonia - requires home remedy
  • Pneumonia - with fast breathing and/or chest indrawing, which requires home therapy with oral amoxicillin.
  • Severe pneumonia - pneumonia with any general danger sign, which requires a referral and injectable therapy. 
Danger signs of severe pneumonia are: 
  • Not able to drink
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Convulsions
  • Lethargic or unconscious
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Severe malnutrition

questions.solution:
The image shows an established case of chronic lymphatic filariasis, where hygiene is being maintained to prevent further disability by secondary bacterial infection. Disability limitation is a mode of intervention in tertiary prevention.

Other options:

Option A: Specific protection is a mode of intervention in primary prevention which aims at limiting the number of cases of a particular disease. This includes immunization, use of specific nutrients, chemoprophylaxis, accident protection, and avoidance of allergens.

Option C: Primary prevention is a level of prevention which is defined as action taken prior to the onset of a disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur. It is accomplished by measures designed to promote general health and well-being.

Option D: Health promotion is a mode of intervention in primary prevention, and is the process of enabling people to increase control over, and improve health. Health promotion may be achieved through health education, environmental modification, nutritional interventions or lifestyle changes.

choices.text: Most commonly associated cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
Infection in early pregnancy causes milder disease
Foetus affected in late pregnancy may have only deafness

questions.solution:
The child presents with the classical triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome.

The earlier the infection occurs in pregnancy the greater the damage is to the fetus.

The major determinant of the extent of fetal infection in Congenital Rubella Syndrome is the gestational age at which fetal transmission occurs.

  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness

questions.text: A nuclear disaster occurs in your state. Which of the following drugs is given prophylactically?
questions.solution:
After a nuclear disaster, Potassium Iodide (KI) is given prophylactically to all people exposed/at risk of exposure to radiation. If taken in time and at the appropriate dosage, KI blocks the thyroid gland uptake of radioactive iodine and thus, reduces the risk of thyroid cancers.

Table salt (while it contains KI), does not contain enough iodine to block uptake of radioactive iodine by the thyroid gland.

questions.text: Discrete probability distribution that expresses probability of a given number of events in a particular time frame is known as:
questions.solution:
Poissons distribution is the probability distribution that describes the chances of an event in a particular time frame.

For example, if you plot the number of patients visiting the OPD of your hospital for a week on a chart, you can conclude that on a particular day(say Monday) there are more number of patients. And if the pattern of patients is similar you can estimate the number of patients in OPD next week or so.

It is usually done for rare events and is depends on μ = λt (where μ defines the number of events in happening in time t)

Other options 
Gaussian distribution is another name for Normal distribution 

Binomial distribution examples consist of those events which can only have two possible results given as yes or no / success or failure. It is usually done for finite number of events unlike Poissons distribution.

questions.solution:
The instrument seen in the image is a Sling Psychrometer, It is used to measure the humidity/ moisture content in the air.

Sling Psychrometer has a 2 mercury thermometers (wet and dry) in it. The wet bulb is moistened first with distilled water and the instrument is whirled / rotated standing with the back to the sun. The reading is noted twice.

Later the dry bulb is taken up for the reading and the relative air humidity is obtained by use of suitable tables and charts.

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

questions.text: Vertical transmission of an infectious agent from parent to progeny in vectors is seen in _______
questions.solution:
Vertical transmission of an infectious agent from parent to progeny in vectors is called transovarial transmission. It is seen in Rickettsia rickettsii (in ticks).

Related Pearl: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

  • The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the p-value?

choices.text: It is equal to the probability of committing a type I error
It is the chance that the presence of difference is concluded when actually there may be none
When the p value is less than α, the result is statistically significant

questions.solution:
The power of a test is 1 – beta.

The p value is the probability that a type I error is being made. It is the chance that the presence of difference is concluded when actually there may be none. When the p value is less than α, the result is statistically significant.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: Anti-larval measures are being taken to control the mosquitoes, which were breeding in a pond. All of the following are fishes, which may be used in biological control, except:
questions.solution:
Cyclops is a crustacean (omnivorous copepod), which belongs to the phylum Arthropoda. It is not a fish. However, the cyclops can also feed on larval stages of some mosquito species, and can be used in biological control.

The larvivorous fishes that can be used for biological control include:

  • Gambusia affinis
  • Lebister reticulatus (Barbados Millions)
  • Poecilia

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites

questions.text:
In a study that investigates the relationship between steroid contraceptives and breast cancer, there is found to be a strong association between age and breast cancer, resulting in a confounding bias. Which of the following is an approach to eliminate such an association?
  1. Restriction
  2. Randomization
  3. Blinding
  4. Pre-Stratification
  5. Deletion
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 2, 4.
 
In the given study age is found to be a confounding factor. Confounding bias in the given study with age as a confounding factor can be eliminated by restriction, randomization, and pre-stratification. 
 
A confounding factor is defined as one associated with both exposure and disease and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. In the given example, if the study is conducted without eliminating the confounding factor, there is an unexpectedly strong association between the confounding factor (e.g.. age) and the disease (e.g., breast cancer)

 Techniques to eliminate confounding factors include:
  • Randomization
  • Matching
  • Stratified randomization
  • Restriction
Randomization is the random allocation of the participants in experimental studies (Randomized control trials) into the study group and control group.

Matching, which is usually done in analytical studies (for example, case-control and cohort studies), is the process where the participants in two groups are matched based on factors such as age, gender, race, smoking status, etc. to eliminate the potential confounders.
 
Stratified randomization, which is also known as pre-stratification or blocking, is the process that combines both randomization and matching techniques. In this method, the participants are first grouped into subgroups that internally match with potential confounding factors such as age, race, gender, etc. An equal number of participants from each subgroup are then allocated to the study and control groups.
 
Restriction: This method restricts the study to only those participants with particular characteristics. For example, a study can be restricted to participants of only one gender, race, age group, geographical area, disease severity, etc., thus eliminating the potential confounders.
 
Other options:
 
Blinding and deletion do not eliminate confounding factors. Blinding is done to eliminate other biases such as subject bias, observer bias, or investigator bias.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding prevalence, except?

choices.text: Refers specifically to all current cases(old and new)
It is a rate in the true sense
Helps to estimate the magnitude of health problems in the community

questions.solution:
Although prevalence is referred to as rate, it is actually a proportion. The term disease prevalence refers specifically to all current cases (old and new) in a given population.

It is represented by the formula :

Prevalence = (Number of existing cases of a specified disease during a given period of time interval / Estimated mid-interval population at-risk) x 100

Prevalence depends upon 2 factors, the incidence, and duration of illness. Given the assumption that the population is stable, and incidence and duration are unchanging, the relationship between incidence and prevalence can be expressed as :

P = I x D   where,

  • P is the prevalence
  • I is the incidence
  • and D is the mean duration of the disease

Prevalence is of two types:

(a) Point prevalence: Point prevalence of a disease is defined as the number of all current cases (old and new) of a disease at one point of time, in relation to a defined population.

(b) Period prevalence: It measures the frequency of all current cases (old and new) existing during a defined period of time (e.g., annual prevalence) expressed in relation to a defined population.

Prevalence helps to estimate the magnitude of health problems in the community and identify potential high-risk populations. Prevalence rates are useful for administrative and planning purposes.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: A cardiologist wants to study the effect of the atorvastatin drug. She measures the initial cholesterol levels of 50 patients. After a month's treatment, she measures the cholesterol level again. Which of the following tests will she use to test the statistical significance of the change in the cholesterol level?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the variable (cholesterol level) is quantitative. Moreover, the comparison is being done before and after the treatment (dependent). Hence, a paired t test will be used.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: The following diagram charts the population change over years from 1983 to 1989 in a given place. What is the statistical diagram used here?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a component bar graph. It is used to represent data in which the total magnitude is divided into different subsets or components.

A bar chart or bar graph is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data. They can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

The image given below shows a multiple bar graph showing the human losses of world war II by country. In a multiple bar chart, 2 or more sets of data are shown simultaneously.  

A bar chart can be distinguished from a histogram because the rectangles are separated by the spaces. This indicates that the data forms discrete categories.

In a histogram, the rectangles are not separated by spaces as the data represented forms a continuous set instead of discrete groups.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: Sample sizes of samples 1, 2 and 3 are 1000, 800, 600 respectively. The order of margin of error will be ____________.
questions.solution:
Curve 1 has the least margin of error, followed by curve 2, and then curve 3. So the order is 3>2>1.

The image shows three normal distribution curves of different sample sizes, having the same mean but different standard deviations.

As the sample size is decreasing, the peak decreases and the curve becomes more flat, implying a wider confidence of interval for the given mean.

The width of the base of the curve is directly proportional to the margin of error. 

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: How efficacious is the hypochlorous acid, when compared to the hypochlorite ions in terms of its disinfecting action?
questions.solution:
Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.

The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

questions.text: A group of health workers is conducting a perinatal mortality audit at a hospital. Which of the following should they not take into account to calculate the perinatal mortality rate?

choices.text: Number of live births per year
Number of late neonatal deaths per year
Number of stillbirths over 1000 g per year
Number of early neonatal deaths per year

questions.solution:
Number of late neonatal deaths per year is not included in the perinatal mortality rate.

The perinatal mortality rate (PMR) is calculated using the following parameters during a particular time period:

  • Late fetal deaths or stillbirths >1000 g - correlates to 28 weeks of gestation
  • Early neonatal deaths - from birth to 7 days of life
  • Live births >1000 g

The neonatal mortality rate (NMR) refers to the rate of deaths within the first 28 days of life. It is calculated using the following parameters:

  • Early neonatal deaths
  • Late neonatal deaths - after 7th day but before 28th completed day of life

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

questions.text: According to WHO recommendations, which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to handling vaccine diluents?

choices.text: Vaccine diluent containing an active substance should not be frozen
Vaccine diluent cannot be replaced with distilled water for injection
Diluent used to reconstitute an oral vaccine can be injected
Vaccine diluent cannot be replaced with a different diluent to the one specified

questions.solution:
According to the WHO recommendations, the diluent used to reconstitute an oral vaccine should never be injected. Diluents for oral vaccines tend to be of significantly large volumes per dose and are not formulated for injection. These diluents may not have sterility characteristics and constituents appropriate for sterile injection. To avoid serious injury to the recipient, neither oral vaccines nor their assigned diluents should ever be injected.

WHO recommendations on handling vaccine diluents :

  •  Never reconstitute a vaccine with a different diluent to the one specified by the manufacturer.
  •  Never replace a vaccine diluent with water for injection
  •  Never inject an oral vaccine or a diluent used to reconstitute an oral vaccine   
  •  Never freeze a vaccine diluent containing an active substance 
  •  Never use a reconstituted vaccine if foreign particulate matter is observed.

questions.text:
Two patients presented to the tuberculosis OPD and were diagnosed with MDR-TB and XDR-TB, respectively. Both of them are resistant to which of the following drugs?
  1. Isoniazid
  2. Rifampicin 
  3. One of Fluoroquinolones 
  4. One of the second line injectables
  5. Linezolid/ Bedaquiline
questions.solution:
Both the patients diagnosed with MDR-TB and XDR-TB are resistant to Isoniazid and Rifampicin.

Muti-drug resistant (MDR) tuberculosis (TB) shows resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin. 

MDR-TB poses a serious problem in the treatment of TB as isoniazid and rifampicin are the most potent first-line drugs. 

The treatment of MDR-TB is curated with drugs grouped into different classes by the world health organization (WHO).

  • Group A: Levofloxacin, bedaquiline, linezolid
  • Group B: Clofazimine, cycloserine
  • Group C: Ethambutol, pyrazinamide, delamanid, ethionamide

In patients treated previously or with additional drug resistance, a longer MDR-TB regimen of 18-20 months is recommended. Drugs belonging to group A are preferred along with one drug from group B whenever possible. A shorter regimen of 6 months including bedaquiline with other drugs can be used in patients not treated before and without extensive disease. In pregnant women with MRD-TB, drugs such as bedaquiline and delamanid should be avoided. 

XDR-TB (extensively drug-resistant TB) is defined as multi-drug resistant  TB (resistant to rifampicin and isoniazid) which is also resistant to one fluoroquinolone (eg. ofloxacin) AND resistant to at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

It is usually seen in patients who have previously received treatment for TB and have either failed to complete treatment or relapsed.

questions.text: Open vial policy is not applicable to which of the following vaccines?
questions.solution:
Open vial policy is not applicable for BCG and measles vaccines.

It is applicable for:

  • DPT
  • TT
  • Hepatitis B vaccine
  • OPV
  • Pentavalent vaccine
  • Rotavirus vaccine (New version with the VVM on the side)

Related Pearl: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

questions.text: All of the following are valid recommendations regarding wound care in cases of category III dog bites, except ______.

choices.text: Wound should be thoroughly washed and dried followed by application of alcohol to the wound
If suturing is unavoidable, rabies immunoglobulin should be infiltrated in the depth and around the wound and suturing should be delayed by a few hours
In life threatening situations, minimal loose sutures maybe applied to arrest bleeding
Routine cauterization of wound should be performed wherever feasible to reduce incidence of nerve infection

questions.solution:
Wound cauterization is not recommended as it leaves a bad scar and does not confer any additional advantage over washing the wound with water and soap.

The following measures should be taken immediately to stop the contraction of rabies:

  • Cleansing - The most important step in the prevention of rabies is washing the affected area with plenty of soap and water under a running tap for 15 minutes. This is a standard procedure that minimizes the contraction of rabies.
  • Chemical treatment - Irrigation of the wound should then be done with virucidal agents like alcohol, tincture, 0.01% solution of aqueous iodine, or povidone-iodine. Even irrigating the wound with cetrimide + chlorhexidine solution can be done. This process eliminates the residual virus in the wound.
  • Suturing - Bite wounds are not sutured generally. If suturing is unavoidable, rabies immunoglobulin should be infiltrated in the depth and around the wound, and suturing should be delayed by a few hours. This delay in suturing allows the diffusion of antibodies in the tissues.
  • In life-threatening situations, minimal loose sutures may be applied to arrest bleeding.
  • Other measures - Local antibiotics and tetanus toxoid should be given.

Different wound categories for post-exposure prophylaxis:

Categories of wound Post-exposure prophylaxis
Category I - touching or feeding animals, licks on intact skin None
Category II - nibbling of uncovered skin, minor scratches, or abrasions
without bleeding		 Immediate vaccination and
local treatment of the wound
Category III- single or multiple transdermal bites or scratches, licks on broken skin contacts with bats Immediate vaccination and
administration of rabies
immunoglobulin; local
treatment of the wound

Post-exposure prophylaxis regimen for rabies:

Intramuscular regimen: In this regimen, 1 ml or 0.5 ml of vaccine is injected into the deltoid in patients with category II and III wounds.

  • Essen regimen: It is a 5-dose regimen in which 1 dose of vaccine is given on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28 each.
  • Zagreb regimen: It is a 4-dose multisite regimen in which 2 doses of vaccine are given on day 0, followed by 1 dose on days 7 and 21 each.

Intradermal regimen: In this regimen, 0.1 ml of injection is given at 2 sites on days 0, 3, 7, and 28 each.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: In a school of 100 children, a child developed measles. Four days later, 3 of her classmates developed measles. What do these intervening four days correspond to?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the first child is the primary case and her classmates are the secondary cases. Hence, the interval between them developing the disease i.e., the intervening four days, is called the serial interval.

The time interval between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case is called serial interval.

By collecting information about a whole series of such disease onsets, the distribution of the secondary cases can be made. From this information, an approximation of the incubation period can be done.

Lead time/lead interval refers to the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Incubatory interval/ incubation period refers to the time period between invasion of a pathogen to appearance of the first sign or symptom.

Latent interval/ latent period refers to the period between disease initiation to detection of the disease. It is usually used for non-infectious diseases and is equivalent to the incubation period. 

Note :

  • Primary case is the first case of a communicable disease introduced into a population unit.  
  • Secondary case is one that develops after contact with the primary case.
  • Index case is the first case that comes to the notice of an investigator or physician.

questions.text: A group of researchers decided to conduct a study evaluating the relationship between thalidomide and fetal anomalies. The study design will be a case-control study. All of the following are advantages of case-control studies except:
questions.solution:
Relative risk can be calculated only in a cohort study and not in a case-control study.

A case-control study or a retrospective study involves two populations- cases and controls. It progresses from effect to cause.
 
Advantages of a case-control study:
  • Relatively quick and cost-effective
  • Easy to carry out
  • Suitable to investigate rare diseases
  • Less risk to subjects
  • Minimal ethical problems
  • Relatively fewer subjects are required

Relative risk refers to the ratio of the incidence of the disease among the exposed to the incidence of the disease among the non-exposed. It directly measures the strength of the association between the cause and the effect. Cohort studies provide a direct estimate of the relative risk since incidence can be calculated. 

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up

    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text: Surveillance data of an endemic disease reveals that most of the children in the area had been affected and had to be hospitalised. However, most of the adults remained asymptomatic carriers. Which category does this disease belong to?
questions.solution:
The disease in question belongs to the category of holoendemic diseases. In such diseases, a higher prevalence and pathogenic response are seen among the children in an area. The adults tend to be either asymptomatic carriers or show reduced damage by the disease process. E.g, malaria.

An endemic disease is a disease that is present constantly in a population or in a given area without importation from outside. E.g, kala-azar in Bihar.

A hyperendemic disease is a disease that is constantly present at high incidence and prevalence among all groups in a population. E.g, dengue in India.

A syndemic is the aggregation of two or more concurrent or sequential epidemics or disease clusters in a population with biological interactions, which exacerbate the prognosis and burden of disease. It is also known as a synergistic epidemic.

Note: Quasiendemic is not a term used in infectious disease epidemiology.

questions.text: A 3-week-old neonate presents to the outpatient for the first time. He was born by vaginal delivery at home and has not received any vaccines. Which of the following vaccines would be indicated at this visit, as per the National Immunization Schedule?
questions.solution:
BCG (Bacille Calmette-Guerin) vaccine would be indicated in this 3-week-old neonate at this visit as per the national immunization schedule. 

BCG is a live attenuated vaccine that can be given soon after birth until 1 year of age. It is given intradermally at the left upper arm. It provides protection against the central nervous system and disseminated tuberculosis. The liquid (fresh) vaccine and the freeze-dried vaccine are the types available. The WHO has recommended the Danish 1331 strain for the production of the BCG vaccine.

After 2-3 weeks of correct vaccine administration a papule develops at the site. Its size increases slowly and breaks into a shallow ulcer covered with a crust. Healing occurs within 6-12 weeks and will leave a permanent tiny round scar, which is a normal reaction. Adverse reactions seen with BCG vaccine administration are pain, swelling, redness, suppurative lymphadenitis, osteomyelitis, etc.

Mission Indradhanush was launched to fully immunize children up to two years of age against seven vaccine-preventable diseases and pregnant women. The vaccines against the following diseases are included in this program diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus, tuberculosis, polio, hepatitis B, and measles. It was later modified to the intensified mission indradhanush to further strengthen the immunization coverage.

Other Options:

Option B: Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine given at birth until the first 24 hours. It is given intramuscularly on the anterolateral side of the mid-thigh. 

Option C: Oral polio vaccine-0 (OPV-0)  is a live attenuated vaccine given at birth until the first 15 days.

Option D: Injectable polio vaccine (IPV) is a killed whole organism vaccine given at 6 and 14 weeks of age.

Related Pearl: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

questions.text: According to the National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India, states are classified based on which of the following parameters?
questions.solution:
The annual parasite incidence (API) is used in classifying states/UTs according to the National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India. 

The Annual Parasite Incidence is calculated as: (Cases in one year ×1000) / (Population under surveillance).

questions.text: In order to effectively prevent endemic goiter, what is the recommended iodine content in salt at the consumer level?
questions.solution:
The recommended level of iodine content in salt is 15 ppm at the consumer level and 30 ppm at the production level.
